channel.name: Recommended way of running snarkyjs in web workers

messages.content:
What is the recommended way of running snarkyjs in a web worker? 

I'm running into issues with snarkyjs relying on `window` for `canvas` access, and its an issue for me since `window` is not available in a Web Worker. I'd appreciate any tips 🙂
cc @gregor @Florian
Should i make a PR that replaces `window` with `self`? Apparently thats the way its meant to be used according to stack overflow. I've tried it locally and it works
What exactly is not working? Have you looked at the web worker tutorial in the docs?

I haven't investigated what setup the tutorial 04 uses to run the web worker, but as per the web worker spec - currently trying with Vite, workers dont have access to `window`, snarkyjs uses `window` instead of the recommended `self` therefore it errors out when i try to load snarky in my worker

the fact that the web worker setup works in the tutorial is probably due to some implicit next.js configuration.

another topic is the top level await, i feel like in the setup i've got, the top level await is of blocking nature when loading my ui
e.g. tools like Parcel don't have top level await support which is unfortunate :/ i'd love if that was an opt-in feature
That’s right, web workers don’t have access to window -  it I thought we weren’t using that and it worked (therefor the tutorial on the docs). But if it’s still an issue we should fix it
there's just a few places where `window` should be replaced with `self` - if you try self in chrome console it gives you window, apparently how its meant to be according to stack overflow
you don’t need to use await anymore, it has been deprecated and should work without - let me know if it doesn’t

+ some safer handling of if certain properties are available on window, in case they are not - like userAgent which used in snarkyjs - so it doesnt blow up in non-dom environments if the web bundle is used
it does work without, but my claim is that importing snarky and using it is therefore a thread blocking operation
i'm trying to build an example where this can be demonstrated, i believe the rendering of my dom content is significantly delayed due to isReady being implicit - using top level await
not sure if this can be solved, perhaps isReady is just blocking even if its behind the scenes, but would be nice to be able to issue a loading screen before

i think its a step backwards not being able to control when snarkyjs 'will load' and forcing waiting for it to load directly on the import.

This will result into users/devs importing snarky dynamically using `await import('snarkyjs')` in order to have control of the top level await

Yeah snarkyjs takes about 2sec to execute at the top level. It's thread blocking if you import it normally.
I agree that this implies you need dynamic import.
To me it feels dynamic import has a similar complexity cost as having to await isReady before doing anything. But it definitely feels less ergonomic because you have to initialize your imports as undefined global variables.
it mainly introduces extra requirements for the underlying UI tooling - needs support for too level await which is an extra toggle always, and in some cases entirely not supported yet
IMO frameworks not supporting tla 2 years after all browsers supported it, is a sign of that framework being dead 💀
yeah true, i just like Parcel a lot haha
so the takeaway here is that snarkyjs should always run in a worker, since it has loong blocking operations no matter the import approach (or other fns like prove)
BTW another reason why this was a problem for me also in a worker is because i use Comlink - a library by google that wraps postMessage
Wait
That wasn't my takeaway 😄 what about dynamic import
Ah yeah for proving, gotcha
and if you import snarkyjs using the toplevel await in your worker, the comlink library execution in-worker is delayed, and they didnt design for top-level await behavior for the comlink api
I already helped one team work around that comlink problem fwiw
mm the dynamic import probably isnt blocking thats true… but i think if you use dynamic import you end up implementing keeping track of ‘isReady’ manually, no?
its simple, just emit an isReady event from the worker before calling the API
at least thats what i did, do you have another approach? dont even need dynamic import for it
@gregor the original issue with window vs self is more pressing tho
That one is weird because I know snarkyjs works in web workers in several examples
But yeah if you find an offending 'window' happy to approve a PR that removes it.
Btw, afaik you should use globalThis, not self, to be compatible with nodejs
yeah i found SO answers pointing to self, but subject to further research
there’s about 6 window references i replaced in my snarky build - namely around window.navigator etc - i assume introduced with the m1 performance improvements
i can make the PR since i’ve got a reproduction case locally - can research self or globalThis too
FYI, I removed window references introduced with the M1 detection in a recent release, to solve exactly this issue. So make sure you're on the last snarkyjs version
let me try later, i was on 0.11.0
On the same note @gregor , it looks like that compiling a zkprogram on node in the backend blocks the main thread. Is that something we can avoid?
Yeah, with some rearchitecting we could make more than half of the compilation and prover time not block the main thread
